canonical_explanation.text:
Morphology deals with the study of external form and structure of plants. Angiosperms (flowering plants) have a well-organised body consisting of roots, stems, leaves, flowers, fruits, and seeds. Roots may be tap roots (dicots) or adventitious/fibrous roots (monocots), and can be modified for storage (fusiform, napiform, conical), support (prop roots, stilt roots), or respiration (pneumatophores). Stems can be modified into tubers, bulbs, rhizomes, corms, runners, stolons, tendrils, thorns, and phylloclades. Leaves vary in shape, venation (reticulate in dicots, parallel in monocots), phyllotaxy (alternate, opposite, whorled), and can be simple or compound (pinnately or palmately compound).

Flowers are the reproductive organs, with parts arranged in whorls: calyx, corolla, androecium, and gynoecium. Inflorescence types include racemose and cymose. Aestivation (arrangement of petals in a bud) can be valvate, twisted, imbricate, or vexillary. Placentation types include marginal, axile, parietal, basal, and free central. Fruits develop from the ovary and are classified as simple, aggregate, or composite. Seeds are either monocotyledonous or dicotyledonous. The families Fabaceae, Solanaceae, and Liliaceae are described in detail with their floral formulae and diagrams.
rules: Tap root system is characteristic of dicots; fibrous root system of monocots.
Stem modifications include tuber (potato), bulb (onion), rhizome (ginger), corm (colocasia), runner (grass), stolon (jasmine).
Reticulate venation is typical of dicots; parallel venation of monocots.
Compound leaves are pinnate (neem) or palmate (silk cotton); simple leaves have undivided lamina.
Racemose inflorescence has acropetal succession; cymose has basipetal succession.
Aestivation: valvate (Calotropis), twisted (China rose), imbricate (Cassia), vexillary/papilionaceous (pea).
Placentation types: marginal (pea), axile (China rose), parietal (mustard), basal (sunflower), free central (Dianthus).
Fabaceae: papilionaceous corolla, diadelphous stamens, marginal placentation.
Solanaceae: tubular calyx, funnel-shaped corolla, epipetalous stamens, axile placentation.
Liliaceae: perianth of 6 tepals, 6 stamens, axile placentation, mostly bulbous plants.

questions.question_text: Tap root system is characteristic of:
questions.explanation_correct: Dicotyledonous plants develop a tap root system where the primary root (radicle) continues to grow and forms the main root with lateral branches.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Monocots develop fibrous (adventitious) root systems. Pteridophytes and bryophytes do not have true roots (bryophytes have rhizoids). Tap root system is a dicot characteristic.

questions.question_text: Pneumatophores are root modifications found in:
questions.explanation_correct: Pneumatophores are breathing roots that grow vertically upward from the soil surface in mangrove plants like Rhizophora and Avicennia. They help in gaseous exchange in waterlogged, oxygen-deficient soil.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Epiphytes have velamen roots. Desert plants have deep tap roots. Parasitic plants have haustoria. Pneumatophores are exclusive to mangrove plants growing in swampy areas.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a stem modification?
questions.explanation_correct: Potato is a stem tuber — an underground stem modification that stores food. The 'eyes' on a potato are axillary buds, confirming its stem nature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sweet potato, radish, and carrot are all root modifications for food storage. Potato is a stem tuber, identified by the presence of nodes (eyes) and internodes.

questions.question_text: Reticulate venation is found in the leaves of:
questions.explanation_correct: Peepal is a dicot plant and exhibits reticulate venation, where veins form a network pattern on the leaf lamina.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wheat, maize, and grass are monocots with parallel venation. Peepal is a dicot showing reticulate venation.

questions.question_text: A student observes a plant with prop roots hanging from the branches that grow into the soil and provide additional support. This plant is most likely:
questions.explanation_correct: Prop roots (pillar roots) are adventitious roots that arise from branches and grow downward into the soil to provide mechanical support. They are characteristic of the banyan tree (Ficus benghalensis).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Maize and sugarcane have stilt roots arising from the basal nodes. Rhizophora has pneumatophores. Prop roots from branches are a feature of the banyan tree.

questions.question_text: Ginger is an underground stem and not a root because it:

options.text: Has nodes, internodes, and scale leaves

questions.explanation_correct: Ginger is a rhizome (underground stem) identified by the presence of nodes, internodes, and scale leaves. These are stem features absent in roots.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Growing underground and storing food are features shared by both modified roots and stems. Colour is not a distinguishing criterion. The presence of nodes, internodes, and scale leaves confirms it is a stem.

questions.question_text: Which type of leaf arrangement is shown by Calotropis?
questions.explanation_correct: Calotropis shows opposite phyllotaxy where two leaves arise at each node, positioned directly opposite each other.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Alternate phyllotaxy (one leaf per node) is seen in sunflower. Whorled phyllotaxy (more than two leaves per node) is seen in Alstonia. Calotropis has opposite phyllotaxy.

questions.question_text: In a pinnately compound leaf, the leaflets are arranged on either side of a common axis called:
questions.explanation_correct: In pinnately compound leaves (e.g., neem), the leaflets are arranged on both sides of a common axis called the rachis, which is an extension of the petiole.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The petiole connects the leaf to the stem. The petiolule is the stalk of individual leaflets. The midrib is the central vein of a simple leaf. The rachis bears leaflets in compound leaves.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a modification of stem?
questions.explanation_correct: Sweet potato is a tuberous root modification for food storage. Onion bulb, potato tuber, and colocasia corm are all underground stem modifications.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Onion (bulb), potato (tuber), and colocasia (corm) are all modified stems. Sweet potato is a modified root, making it the correct answer.

questions.question_text: Assertion (A): Tendrils in cucumber are stem modifications. Reason (R): They arise from axillary buds and help in climbing.

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R correctly explains A
Both A and R are true, but R does not correctly explain A
A is true but R is false
A is false but R is true

questions.explanation_correct: In cucumber, tendrils are modified stems that arise from axillary buds. Their origin from buds confirms stem nature, and they help the plant climb for support.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both statements are true. The fact that tendrils arise from axillary buds (a stem character) is the reason they are classified as stem modifications. Note: In pea, tendrils are leaf modifications.

questions.question_text: In Opuntia (prickly pear), the flattened green stem that performs photosynthesis is called:
questions.explanation_correct: In Opuntia, the green flattened stem that carries out photosynthesis is called a phylloclade. Phylloclades are modified stems with multiple nodes and internodes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A cladode is a one-internode stem (e.g., Asparagus). A phyllode is a modified petiole (e.g., Acacia). Thorns are modified stem branches. Opuntia has phylloclades.

questions.question_text: The fusiform shape of root (swollen in the middle and tapering at both ends) is seen in:
questions.explanation_correct: Radish has a fusiform (spindle-shaped) root that is swollen in the middle and tapering towards both ends.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carrot has a conical root (broad at top, tapering at base). Turnip has a napiform root (spherical at top). Sweet potato has tuberous roots. Radish has a fusiform shape.

questions.question_text: The arrangement of flowers on the floral axis is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Inflorescence refers to the arrangement of flowers on the floral axis (peduncle). The two main types are racemose and cymose.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Phyllotaxy is the arrangement of leaves. Aestivation is the arrangement of sepals or petals in a bud. Placentation is the arrangement of ovules in the ovary. Inflorescence refers to flower arrangement.

questions.question_text: In racemose inflorescence, the order of flower opening is:
questions.explanation_correct: In racemose inflorescence, the main axis continues to grow and flowers open in acropetal succession — older flowers at the base and younger ones at the apex.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Basipetal succession (apex to base) is found in cymose inflorescence. Racemose inflorescence always shows acropetal succession from base to apex.

questions.question_text: How many whorls are typically present in a complete flower?
questions.explanation_correct: A complete flower has four whorls: calyx (sepals), corolla (petals), androecium (stamens), and gynoecium (carpels).
questions.explanation_incorrect: A flower that has all four whorls — calyx, corolla, androecium, and gynoecium — is called complete. Two or three whorls would make it incomplete.

questions.question_text: In which type of aestivation do the margins of petals overlap one another in a whorl, but not in any particular direction?
questions.explanation_correct: In imbricate aestivation, the margins of petals overlap one another but not in a definite direction. Example: Cassia (Gulmohar).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Valvate — petals touch without overlapping. Twisted — each petal overlaps the next in one direction. Vexillary — one large petal overlaps two lateral, which overlap two smallest. Imbricate has irregular overlapping.

questions.question_text: Marginal placentation is found in:
questions.explanation_correct: In pea (Fabaceae), the ovary is unilocular and ovules develop on the margin of the single carpel — this is marginal placentation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mustard has parietal placentation. Sunflower has basal placentation. Lemon has axile placentation. Pea is the classic example of marginal placentation.

questions.question_text: When the ovary is situated above the other floral parts on the thalamus, the flower is said to be:
questions.explanation_correct: In hypogynous flowers, the ovary is superior — it is placed above other floral parts on the thalamus. The gynoecium occupies the highest position. Examples include mustard and brinjal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In epigynous flowers, the ovary is inferior. In perigynous flowers, the ovary is half-inferior. Syncarpous refers to fused carpels, not ovary position.

questions.question_text: Axile placentation is found in flowers with:

options.text: Multilocular ovary with ovules on the central axis
Ovules at the base of the ovary

questions.explanation_correct: In axile placentation, the ovary is multilocular and ovules are borne on the central axis. Examples include China rose, tomato, and lemon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Unilocular ovary with ovules on the wall is parietal placentation. Ovules at the base is basal placentation. Axile placentation requires a multilocular ovary with a central axis.

questions.question_text: In Calotropis, the sepals in the bud touch each other at the margins without overlapping. This type of aestivation is:
questions.explanation_correct: Valvate aestivation is when the margins of sepals or petals touch each other without overlapping. Calotropis is a classic example of valvate aestivation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Twisted aestivation has regular overlapping in one direction. Imbricate has irregular overlapping. Vexillary is specific to papilionaceous flowers. Calotropis shows valvate aestivation.

questions.question_text: Which of the following represents parietal placentation?

options.text: Ovules on the margin of a monocarpellary ovary
Ovules on the inner wall of a unilocular, syncarpous ovary
Ovules on the central axis of a multilocular ovary
Ovule at the base of the ovary

questions.explanation_correct: In parietal placentation, the ovary is unilocular (or becomes so) and the ovules develop on the inner wall (parietal region) of the ovary. Examples: mustard, Argemone.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is marginal placentation. Option C is axile placentation. Option D is basal placentation. Parietal placentation has ovules on the inner wall of a syncarpous, unilocular ovary.

questions.question_text: Free central placentation is found in:
questions.explanation_correct: In Dianthus (carnation), ovules are borne on a central column in a unilocular ovary without any septa — this is free central placentation. Also seen in Primrose.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pea has marginal placentation. Mustard has parietal. Sunflower has basal. Dianthus shows free central placentation.

questions.question_text: When stamens are attached to the petals, they are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Epipetalous stamens are those attached to the petals. This is common in Solanaceae family (e.g., brinjal, petunia).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Epiphyllous means stamens attached to the perianth (tepals). Synandrous means all stamens fused together. Syngenesious means anthers fused but filaments free. Epipetalous means attached to petals.

questions.question_text: A flower has a superior ovary and the sepals, petals, and stamens appear to arise below the ovary. Such a flower is called:
questions.explanation_correct: In a hypogynous flower, the ovary is superior, and all other floral whorls arise from below the ovary on the thalamus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Epigynous = inferior ovary (other parts above). Perigynous = half-inferior ovary. Apocarpous refers to free carpels. Hypogynous describes the arrangement with a superior ovary.

questions.question_text: A fruit that develops from the ovary of a single flower with a single carpel or multiple fused carpels is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Simple fruits develop from the ovary of a single flower with one carpel or multiple fused carpels. They can be fleshy (berry, drupe) or dry (legume, capsule).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Aggregate fruits develop from a flower with multiple free carpels. Composite fruits develop from the entire inflorescence. Parthenocarpic fruits develop without fertilisation.

questions.question_text: Mango is an example of which type of fruit?
questions.explanation_correct: Mango is a drupe — a fleshy fruit with a hard stony endocarp enclosing the seed, a fleshy mesocarp (edible part), and a thin exocarp (skin).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Berry has a fleshy pericarp without a hard endocarp (e.g., tomato). Pome has fleshy thalamus (e.g., apple). Capsule is a dry fruit. Mango is a drupe.

questions.question_text: The part of the seed that gives rise to the root system is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The radicle is the embryonic root within the seed that develops into the root system upon germination.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The plumule gives rise to the shoot system. Cotyledons are seed leaves for food storage. Endosperm is the nutritive tissue. The radicle develops into the root.

questions.question_text: Apple is a false fruit because the fleshy edible part is derived from the:
questions.explanation_correct: In apple (a pome), the fleshy edible part develops from the thalamus (receptacle), not the ovary. Hence it is called a false fruit (pseudocarp). The true fruit (from the ovary) is the core.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A true fruit develops from the ovary wall. In apple, the thalamus becomes the edible part, making it a false fruit. The calyx and pedicel do not form the edible part.

questions.question_text: Seeds that retain the endosperm at maturity are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Endospermic (albuminous) seeds retain the endosperm even at maturity. Examples include castor, maize, and wheat. In non-endospermic seeds, the endosperm is consumed during development.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Non-endospermic seeds (e.g., pea, gram) use up the endosperm during development. Endospermic seeds like maize and castor retain the endosperm for nourishment.

questions.question_text: The scutellum in a monocot seed is a modified:
questions.explanation_correct: In monocot seeds (e.g., maize), the single cotyledon is called the scutellum. It lies adjacent to the endosperm and absorbs nutrients from it during germination.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The scutellum is a modified cotyledon, not endosperm or seed coat. It acts as an interface between the embryo and the endosperm in monocot seeds.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a parthenocarpic fruit?
questions.explanation_correct: Banana is a parthenocarpic fruit — it develops without fertilisation and is therefore seedless. Parthenocarpy can occur naturally or be induced artificially.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mango, apple, and coconut all develop after fertilisation and contain seeds. Banana develops without fertilisation, making it seedless and parthenocarpic.

questions.question_text: The seed coat of a monocot seed is fused with the fruit wall (pericarp) to form:
questions.explanation_correct: In cereal grains (e.g., maize, wheat), the seed coat is fused with the pericarp (fruit wall), forming a structure called a caryopsis. The grain is actually a fruit, not just a seed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Testa and tegmen are separate layers of the seed coat in dicots. In monocot grains (caryopsis), the seed coat and pericarp are inseparable.

questions.question_text: The hilum on a seed is:

options.text: The scar where the seed was attached to the fruit

questions.explanation_correct: The hilum is a scar on the seed coat marking the point where the seed was attached to the fruit (funiculus). It is visible as a small oval mark.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The micropyle is the pore for water absorption. The testa is the protective outer coat. The plumule is the embryonic shoot. The hilum is the attachment scar.

questions.question_text: Tomato is an example of which type of fruit?
questions.explanation_correct: Tomato is a berry — a fleshy fruit in which the entire pericarp is fleshy and encloses one or more seeds. Other examples include grape and banana.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A drupe has a hard stony endocarp (e.g., mango). A pome has fleshy thalamus (e.g., apple). A legume is a dry dehiscent fruit (e.g., pea). Tomato is a berry.

questions.question_text: An aggregate fruit develops from:

options.text: A single carpel of a flower
Multiple free carpels of a single flower

questions.explanation_correct: An aggregate fruit (etaerio) develops from a flower that has multiple free carpels (apocarpous gynoecium). Each carpel develops into a fruitlet. Example: strawberry, raspberry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A single carpel gives a simple fruit. An entire inflorescence gives a composite fruit. Aggregate fruits arise from multiple free carpels of a single flower.

questions.question_text: Which family is characterised by a papilionaceous corolla?
questions.explanation_correct: Fabaceae (Papilionaceae) is characterised by the papilionaceous (butterfly-shaped) corolla consisting of a standard (vexillum), two wings (alae), and a keel (carina).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Solanaceae has a tubular or funnel-shaped corolla. Liliaceae has a perianth of six tepals. Brassicaceae has cruciform corolla. The papilionaceous corolla is unique to Fabaceae.

questions.question_text: The stamens in Fabaceae are typically:
questions.explanation_correct: In Fabaceae, the 10 stamens are typically diadelphous — 9 stamens have their filaments fused into a bundle and 1 stamen (the posterior one) remains free.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Monadelphous = all filaments fused into one bundle (e.g., China rose). Epipetalous = attached to petals (e.g., Solanaceae). Fabaceae characteristically shows diadelphous stamens (9+1).

questions.question_text: Which of the following plants belongs to family Solanaceae?
questions.explanation_correct: Petunia belongs to family Solanaceae along with tomato, brinjal, potato, tobacco, and Datura.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pea belongs to Fabaceae. Onion belongs to Liliaceae. Wheat belongs to Poaceae. Petunia is a member of Solanaceae.

questions.question_text: A plant has actinomorphic flowers, five epipetalous stamens, bicarpellary syncarpous ovary with axile placentation, and berry-type fruits. It belongs to:
questions.explanation_correct: Solanaceae is characterised by actinomorphic flowers, five epipetalous stamens, bicarpellary syncarpous ovary with axile placentation, and berry fruits (e.g., tomato, brinjal).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fabaceae has zygomorphic flowers and diadelphous stamens. Liliaceae has six stamens and trimerous flowers. The described features perfectly match Solanaceae.

questions.question_text: Flowers in Liliaceae are typically:
questions.explanation_correct: Liliaceae flowers are trimerous (floral parts in multiples of three) and actinomorphic (radially symmetrical). They have 6 tepals, 6 stamens, and a tricarpellary ovary.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pentamerous flowers are found in Solanaceae and Fabaceae. Tetramerous in Brassicaceae. Liliaceae flowers are trimerous and actinomorphic.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly describes the fruit type in Fabaceae?
questions.explanation_correct: The characteristic fruit of Fabaceae is the legume (pod), which is a dry, dehiscent fruit that splits along two sutures on maturity. Examples: pea pod, bean pod.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Berry is characteristic of Solanaceae. Capsule is characteristic of Liliaceae. Drupe is not typical of Fabaceae. The legume is the hallmark fruit of Fabaceae.

questions.question_text: The floral formula for Solanaceae can be written as:

options.text: Actinomorphic, bisexual, K(5) C(5) A5 G(2)
Zygomorphic, bisexual, K(5) C1+2+(2) A(9)+1 G1
Actinomorphic, bisexual, K(5) C5 A(many) G(5)

questions.explanation_correct: Solanaceae: actinomorphic, bisexual, calyx (5) gamosepalous, corolla (5) gamopetalous, 5 epipetalous stamens, bicarpellary syncarpous superior ovary G(2).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is Fabaceae. Option C is Liliaceae. The Solanaceae floral formula is characterised by pentamerous, actinomorphic flowers with fused sepals and petals.

questions.question_text: Which of the following plants belongs to family Liliaceae?
questions.explanation_correct: Allium (onion) is a member of family Liliaceae. Other members include Aloe, Asparagus, Colchicum, Gloriosa, and lily.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tomato belongs to Solanaceae. Mustard to Brassicaceae. Sunflower to Asteraceae. Allium (onion) is a classic member of Liliaceae.

questions.question_text: In Fabaceae, the type of placentation is:
questions.explanation_correct: Fabaceae has a monocarpellary, unilocular ovary with marginal placentation — ovules are attached along the ventral suture (margin) of the single carpel.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Axile placentation is found in Solanaceae and Liliaceae. Parietal in Brassicaceae. Marginal placentation is characteristic of Fabaceae.

questions.question_text: The perianth in Liliaceae consists of:

options.text: Six tepals arranged in two whorls of three each

questions.explanation_correct: In Liliaceae, the calyx and corolla are not differentiated. Instead, there are six tepals (perianth members) arranged in two whorls of three each (3+3).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Liliaceae does not have distinct sepals and petals. The perianth consists of 6 tepals (petaloid) in two whorls. This undifferentiated perianth is a key feature of the family.

questions.question_text: The standard (vexillum) in a papilionaceous corolla is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The standard (vexillum) is the largest posterior petal in the papilionaceous corolla. It overlaps the two lateral wing petals (alae), which in turn overlap the two anterior petals forming the keel (carina).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The two lateral petals are the wings (alae). The two anterior fused petals form the keel (carina). The standard is the largest, outermost posterior petal.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a stem tendril?
questions.explanation_correct: The tendril of grape vine (Vitis) is a stem modification. It develops from axillary buds. In pea and sweet pea, tendrils are leaf modifications. In Gloriosa, the tendril is a leaf-tip modification.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pea and sweet pea have leaf tendrils. Gloriosa has a leaf apex tendril. Grape vine has stem tendrils that arise from axillary buds.

questions.question_text: A zygomorphic flower can be divided into two equal halves through:
questions.explanation_correct: A zygomorphic (bilaterally symmetrical) flower can be divided into two equal halves only along one vertical plane. Example: pea, bean (Fabaceae).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Actinomorphic flowers can be divided through any vertical plane. Asymmetric flowers cannot be divided into equal halves through any plane. Zygomorphic needs exactly one vertical plane.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of a dicot seed?
questions.explanation_correct: Many dicot seeds (e.g., pea, gram) are non-endospermic — the endosperm is consumed during seed development and stored in the cotyledons. So endosperm is NOT always present at maturity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Two cotyledons, distinct testa and tegmen, and hilum/micropyle are all typical of dicot seeds. But endosperm is not always retained — many dicots are non-endospermic.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a common economic importance of family Fabaceae?

options.text: Members fix atmospheric nitrogen through root nodules

questions.explanation_correct: Many members of Fabaceae (e.g., pea, gram, bean) harbour nitrogen-fixing bacteria (Rhizobium) in their root nodules. This enriches soil nitrogen, making them important in crop rotation and sustainable agriculture.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fabaceae members are not all poisonous, aquatic, or only ornamental. Their key economic importance includes nitrogen fixation, pulses, fodder, and timber.
